content.subtitle: Today, we‚Äôre excited to announce the release of Dart 3.10!

paragraphs.text: Announcing Dart 3.10

paragraphs.name: f30d
paragraphs.text: Today, we‚Äôre excited to announce the release of Dart 3.10!

paragraphs.name: c1ce
paragraphs.text: Announcing Dart 3.10

paragraphs.name: b0b7
paragraphs.text: This release continues our focus on improving the core developer experience. The new dot shorthands (.) feature will help you write more readable and less verbose code. We‚Äôre also introducing a powerful new analyzer plugin system that allows you to create custom static analysis rules that integrate directly into your IDE. And we‚Äôre excited to announce that build hooks are now stable!

paragraphs.name: 98f9
paragraphs.text: This release also brings several improvements to pub.dev and package management. You‚Äôll find new search capabilities in the ‚ÄúLikes‚Äù tab in your profile, and package authors can now disable manual publishing for improved security. Finally, we‚Äôve added a suite of new, more specific deprecation annotations to give you finer-grained control over your API‚Äôs evolution.
Read on to learn more about these and the other improvements in Dart 3.10.

paragraphs.name: ff89
paragraphs.text: Language updates

paragraphs.name: f2d6
paragraphs.text: Dot shorthands üÜï

paragraphs.name: 9ad1
paragraphs.text: Dart 3.10 introduces dot shorthands (.). This new feature lets you omit redundant class or enum names when the compiler can infer the type from the context.
Let‚Äôs look at a common scenario: logging. Before, you might have written:

paragraphs.name: 891a
abb5
paragraphs.text: Since the level parameter already expects a LogLevel, repeating the enum name is unnecessary. With dot shorthands, you can now write:

paragraphs.name: eeeb
f7e3
paragraphs.text: The code now focuses on the value (.error) rather than the type (LogLevel).

paragraphs.name: 5ac0
paragraphs.text: Dot shorthands aren‚Äôt just for enums. You can also use them with constructors, static methods, and static fields. To learn more, read our Dot shorthands guide.
Tools updates
Analyzer plugins üÜï

paragraphs.name: c6bc
paragraphs.text: Have you ever been reviewing code and thought, ‚ÄúShouldn‚Äôt the analyzer be able to catch that?‚Äù. Now it can.

paragraphs.name: d963
paragraphs.text: Dart 3.10 introduces a powerful new plugin system for the Dart analyzer. This allows you to write and use your own static analysis rules that integrate directly into IDEs and command-line tools like dart analyze and flutter analyze. You can use analyzer plugins to:

paragraphs.name: f695
paragraphs.text: Enforce project-specific rules, such as bespoke lints and warnings to maintain conventions in your team‚Äôs codebase.

paragraphs.name: 078c
paragraphs.text: Avoid common pitfalls and best practices specific to your domain.

paragraphs.name: 33c2
paragraphs.text: Automate code changes by providing quick fixes and assists to help automatically correct issues or migrate to new APIs.

This new system is the result of a significant architectural effort to enable a rich ecosystem of community-driven tools, and we‚Äôd like to extend a special thanks to community contributor Felipe Morschel for his valuable fixes and features for the analyzer in general.

paragraphs.name: f880
paragraphs.text: To use an analyzer plugin, simply add it to your analysis_options.yaml file:

paragraphs.name: db8f
paragraphs.text:
analyzer:
  plugins:
    - some_plugin
    - another_plugin

paragraphs.name: a13e
paragraphs.text: To learn more about creating your own custom rules, see the documentation for writing an analyzer plugin.

paragraphs.name: 2c68
paragraphs.text: Build hooks üöÄ

paragraphs.name: 1b4f
paragraphs.text: Integrating native code (like C++, Rust, or Swift) into a Dart package has often required managing complex, platform-specific build files like CMake or Gradle. With Dart 3.10, this process is now dramatically simpler.

paragraphs.name: c146
paragraphs.text: We‚Äôre excited to announce that build hooks (formerly known as native assets) are now stable. You can use these hooks to compile native code or download native assets (like dynamic libraries) and bundle them directly with your Dart package. This powerful capability lets you reuse existing native code or libraries from within your package and eliminates the need to write separate build files such as SPM, Gradle, or CMake for different operating systems.

paragraphs.name: 2fde
paragraphs.text: To learn more, see the documentation for writing a build hook, or watch the Flutter Build show episode on build hooks.

paragraphs.name: f3ac
paragraphs.text: Remove Deprecations lint üÜï

paragraphs.name: dc8c
paragraphs.text: When you release a new major version of a package (like 1.0.0 or 0.2.0), it‚Äôs a best practice to remove any APIs you previously marked as deprecated. This keeps your package clean and prevents developers from using outdated code. However, it‚Äôs easy to forget this step during the release process.

paragraphs.name: ba7d
paragraphs.text: To help, we‚Äôve introduced a new lint: remove_deprecations_in_breaking_versions. This lint detects leftover deprecated elements when a package‚Äôs version is updated to a new major breaking version. By flagging these cases, the lint helps ensure that your package‚Äôs API remains modern and easy for your users to understand.
remove_deprecations_in_breaking_versions lint example

paragraphs.name: 34e4
paragraphs.text: @Deprecated annotation ‚¨ÜÔ∏è

paragraphs.name: de69
paragraphs.text: The existing @Deprecated annotation is a blunt instrument. It informs developers that an API is no longer recommended, but it doesn‚Äôt allow for nuance. For example, how do you signal that a class should no longer be extended, but can still be instantiated?

paragraphs.name: da31
paragraphs.text: To give package authors more precise control over their API‚Äôs evolution, Dart 3.10 introduces a suite of new, more specific deprecation annotations.

paragraphs.name: 3db5
paragraphs.text: You can now deprecate specific use cases for classes and mixins:

paragraphs.name: e973
paragraphs.text: @Deprecated.extend(): The ability to extend a class is deprecated.

paragraphs.name: 60eb
paragraphs.text: @Deprecated.implement(): The ability to implement a class or mixin is deprecated.

paragraphs.name: c34a
paragraphs.text: @Deprecated.subclass(): The ability to subclass (extend or implement) a class or mixin is deprecated.

paragraphs.name: 2b7d
paragraphs.text: @Deprecated.mixin(): The ability to mix in a class is deprecated.
@Deprecated.instantiate(): The ability to instantiate a class is deprecated.

paragraphs.name: bc95
paragraphs.text: Additionally, you can now signal that an optional parameter will become required in a future version using @Deprecated.optional().
Pub updates

paragraphs.name: c5e4
paragraphs.text: Search, sort, and unlike support for your favorite packages üÜï

Managing your favorite packages on pub.dev just got a major upgrade. You can do this through the Search feature or the Likes tab on your profile, where you can now search, sort, and filter your liked packages with the same familiar controls you use for regular searches. This includes sorting by likes, pub points, and popularity. We‚Äôve also improved the UI for unliking packages, making it easier than ever to keep your list of liked packages tidy and up-to-date.
Search, sort, and unlike support for your favorite packages in your Likes tab
If you choose to search for your liked packages with the Search feature, simply add is:liked-by-me to your query.

paragraphs.name: 91e3
paragraphs.text: Search, but only include packages you like

paragraphs.name: 82a2
paragraphs.text: Enable or disable manual publishing üÜï

To enhance security and prevent accidental publications, you can now disable manual publishing (pub publish) for your packages. This is ideal for packages that have an automated publishing workflow or are no longer being actively published.

paragraphs.name: 72e8
paragraphs.text: By disabling manual publishing, you prevent package updates using personal credentials, reducing the risk of an unauthorized or accidental release.

paragraphs.name: 84bf
paragraphs.text: You can control this feature in your package‚Äôs Admin tab using the ‚ÄúEnable manual publishing‚Äù checkbox.

paragraphs.name: e918
paragraphs.text: Enable or disable manual publishing in the Admin tab

paragraphs.name: 3a42
paragraphs.text: Wrap up

paragraphs.name: d138
paragraphs.text: The Dart 3.10 release brings a host of improvements focused on developer productivity, tooling, and the overall health of the package ecosystem. From language features like dot shorthands that make your code more concise, to powerful new tooling capabilities like analyzer plugins and stable build hooks, we hope this release empowers you to build even better apps.
We‚Äôre incredibly grateful for the many engineers and teams who contributed to this release, including a special thanks to our community contributors who help make Dart better for everyone.

paragraphs.name: 4e19
paragraphs.text: We‚Äôre excited to see what you build with Dart 3.10. To get started, you can get the Dart 3.10 SDK today. For a complete list of all the new and updated features, check out the Dart SDK changelog.

virtuals.subtitle: Today, we‚Äôre excited to announce the release of Dart 3.10!
